8. Then shall I teach you to trace three circles
of fixed measurement, such that one is the buttocks,
the other, the breast, and let the third serve
as the torso, then carefully create
the arc of the neck, and show everything
without casting off Proportion?
Desire is light as a feather; power, as heavy as lead:
wanting and being able do not live together in all houses.

9. Therefore it is difficult, and I have no wish
to endorse this measurement to you, nor to achieve
a heavy manner. And as I teach you
the secrets of Art without illustration,
but alone in writing with the pen,
I will help you understand
the circumstances that are necessary above all.
First, attend to the beauty of the Horse.
right-middleMy intention is to instruct without illustrations, but only in writing.

10. Pay close attention to the well-made Horse:
the horns of the hooves gleam like agate,
dark, smooth, high and rounded;
his hocks short, neither too curvy nor too straight,
forelegs long and slender to behold.
The tendons and veins of the knees are modeled well,
with lean muscles, indeed, so that they resemble
nothing so much as a Deerâ€™s.
right-middleThe form and beauty of the Horse.

11. The breast should be made broad and fat,
the shoulders and withers likewise;
the flanks rounded, the belly short, the back without a curve,
The barrel large, with a ridge running along it.
The neck will appear long, wide and full of folds,
A long mane spreads down the right side,
The tail will hang towards the Earth,
Or it shall be elegantly tied up.

12. The buttocks should be round, quivering with fat,
but the head should be small, lean and dry,
the forehead should be made of nothing but bone,
and the ears, sharp and never still.
The mouth should be large, and the nostrils, and the eyes
Also large and staring, darting here and there,
The hair can be given the most suitable color,
Just like many examples one has seen in life.

13. Let us speak a little about the color.
In his Georgics, Maro relates:
chestnut, gray, these are the most magnificent;
the white and sorrel are the.
But Painters, learn freely all that you wish,
and paint dappled, white, and sorrel
right-middleThe Painter should choose his own order in coloring Horses or other Beasts.
